case_vignette: A 17-year-old teenage boy is brought to the emergency room for severe right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain for the past 5 hours. He denies any precipitating events and reports a sharp, 8/10, constant pain at the RUQ. He denies any past episodes. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he is up to date on his vaccinations. His mother reports a “blood disease” on his father’s side. His temperature is 101.0°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. A physical examination demonstrates pale conjunctiva, RUQ tenderness with positive Murphy sign, and splenomegaly. An abdominal ultrasound is shown in Figure A.
question: Which  laboratory findings will confirm this patient’s diagnosis?

* Negative blood cultures

It is important to note that these findings may not be present in all cases of appendicitis, and other causes of RUQ pain should also be considered. A CT scan or MRI of the abdomen and pelvis may also be ordered to confirm the diagnosis.
trial_4.singleturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Positive osmotic fragility test.
trial_4.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Elevated white blood cell count and neutrophil count in the blood, along with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) level, suggestive of appendicitis.
trial_4.summarized_mcq: The correct answer is: Low hemoglobin with decreased mean corpuscular volume.
